awd_titl_txt: Data-enabled Decision-Making in Emerging Co-opetitive Transportation Markets with Ambiguity
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent communications and technological advancements, along with a growing abundance of sensor and user data, enable new mechanisms of cooperation and matching of transportation services to demand. These newfound capabilities highlight changes in moving transportation systems from centrally controlled, publicly owned and operated infrastructures to decentralized system elements. These systems involve multiple stakeholders who operate in competitive environments wherein individuals or facilities may be linked through an underlying common market problem creating benefit from cooperation. That is, these environments are co-opetitive. The overarching objective of this research project is to develop and test concepts that frame dynamic, uncertain and decentralized transportation problems in newly arising co-opetitive environments and create efficient, data-enabled optimization and equilibrium algorithms to support the operation of these future transport services. Developed methods will aid in operating peer-to-peer systems, where individuals can become suppliers, as well as system aggregators. The models and solution methods will exploit personalized information to customize services to individual system users and to better understand transportation systems of the future. Thus, this work will enable assessment of novel market concepts and mechanisms for regulating them. Through the development of an on-line library of e-learning snippets in the form of blog posts, vignettes and video clips, and efforts to involve underrepresented persons and first-generation college students, this project will broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research and positively impact engineering education.

Concepts from game theory, probability modeling and ambiguity, data analytics, and model predictive control will be employed and extended for use in real-time multi-player, multi-level, ambiguous settings with high dimensionality. Closed-form solutions will be accompanied by rigorous mathematical derivation and proof. Solution methods that can be applied both for long-term decision horizons and real-time implementations will be created. Both will take advantage of information through learning about consumer/user behavior and that of competitors. This work aims to support transformation of the field of transportation, bringing concepts from diverse areas of economics, mathematics and control to envision and run markets and collaborations of the future, while simultaneously providing lasting value through fundamental contributions to both modeling and solution methodology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project created efficient, data-enabled optimization methods for supporting the operation of future transportation services operating in co-opetitive, data-rich yet stochastic environments. To this end, this project developed mathematical models, exact, approximate and heuristic solution algorithms, stochastic discrete event simulators, simulation-optimization methodologies and multi-agent deep reinforcement learning methods for the conceptualization and solution of decision problems arising in four key emerging areas. Contribution highlights by area and added general methodological advancements are described.

 (1)   Crowdsourced Event Parking

This project introduced the Crowdsourced Event Parking Market Pricing Problem wherein parking lot owners and others who are willing to rent privately owned spaces compete to attract drivers who are looking for available parking spots. The problem of competitively pricing the spaces was conceptualized with a time-differentiated stochastic equilibrium problem with equilibrium constraints formulation. A diagonalization solution method with embedded scenario sampling and gradient ascent methods was proposed for its solution. Extending the crowd-sourced parking market concept to real-time operations, a model-free, real-time multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach, with formulation and required Markov Decision Process reformulation, for smart dynamic parking pricing in competitive environments was developed.

(2)   Same-Day Delivery

This project conceptualized and formulated a Same-Day Delivery Time-Guarantee (SDDTG) problem to meet the needs of a growing e-commerce based, time-sensitive market. The goal of the SDDTG problem is to find the optimal delivery deadline to offer customers as they consider making purchases. The model seeks to maximize customer satisfaction, increasing purchase decision likelihood, while simultaneously accounting for delivery-related, supply-side costs that can affect profits. The SDDTG problem was conceptualized as a multi-stage, stochastic, mixed-integer program in which uncertainties associated with customer reaction to delivery-deadline offers and their arrival over time are captured. Given a shrinking horizon over a fixed planning horizon, the multi-stage stochastic program is approximated by a series of two-stage stochastic programs, each of which is solved by a parallel implementation of a progressive hedging algorithm.

(3)   Road-use Prioritization

Complimenting recent proposals for reservation-based, autonomous intersection management, the project proposed novel lane-use and lane-reservation policies that ensure that connected and automated vehicles (CAVs) are not delayed at intersections with traditional lane and intersection geometries by circumstances other than the preferences of vehicles with higher priority. Also considered was the dynamically altering of vehicle priorities and lane-use policies to achieve a wide variety of network performance goals. The proposed concepts were tested in a developed agent-based simulation model.

(4)   Meal Delivery

Food delivery services have also grown significantly and are increasingly supported by at-will drivers who are willing to perform delivery jobs for gig-based compensation. Job flexibility, including a flexible work schedule and ability to work for multiple delivery platforms, makes these delivery jobs attractive to drivers. However, the autonomy that attracts drivers to these jobs can leave a company without delivery capacity, resulting in orders waiting undesirable durations for pick up. This project addressed several pertinent problem classes:

(a)   Limiting curbside pickup capacity for meal delivery in COVID-19;

(b)   Taking the courier’s perspective to decide how to pre-position oneself when idle and whether to take a job offer when given;

(c)   Evaluating efficiency gains and risks of relying on an at-will workforce in meal delivery;

(d)   Surge pricing to entice more at-will drivers during periods of high demand; and

(e)   Green meal delivery, incorporating cargo bicycle-based delivery agents, to reach emissions reduction targets with acceptable customer service.

          Techniques from simulation-optimization, multi-agent DRL, constrained Bayesian optimization, and tabu search with embedded ejection chain methodology were developed. A few highlights from this work include:

(1)   Development of deep temporal extreme value models to capture extreme demand and trends with temporal dependencies that contribute to wider understanding of building non-linear predictive regression models (flexible nonlinear approximators) applied in the project for peaks in energy demand time series data and used to address problems with ambiguity;

(2)   Development of deep learning-based transformation functions that map a simulator’s inputs into a latent subspace so that the relations between latent variables and simulator outputs are homoscedastic and standard uncertainty quantification techniques, such as Gaussian process, can be used;

(3)   Explicit modeling of probabilistic problem elements or learning techniques that incorporate uncertainty in the parameters/distributions;

(4)   Techniques that address large-scale, high-dimensionality, and efficiency needs of real-time competitive market applications;

(5)   Created concepts and methodological steps for incorporating personalized historical data for agents acting in multi-agent settings with uncertain attributes and information on the changing environment and prior decisions of competitors.

          Additional analytical/algorithmic advancements were made with general applicability and special emphasis on multi-agent, competitive and collaborative environments. Educational project outcomes include: (1) involvement of underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students in research and publication authorship, (2) new course modules and courses, and (3) techniques that explicitly consider issues of public health and sustainable operations.
